[[Pictor]] [[40th parallel north|40]] [[South Pole|90]] January CaelumIPAc-enˈsiːləmis a faintconstellationin thesouthern sky, introduced in the 1750s byNicolas Louis de Lacaille. Its name means "chisel" inLatin, and it was formerly known asCaelum Scalptorium("the engravers' chisel"); a rare word, unconnected with the far more common Latincaelum, meaning "sky, heaven, atmosphere".Charlton T. Lewis, Ph.D. and. Charles Short,A Latin DictionaryOxford University Press, 1879. Entries forcaelumandcaelum.It is the eighth-smallest constellation, and subtends asolid angleof around 0.038steradians, just less than that ofCorona Australis.

Due to its small size and location away from the plane of theMilky Way, Caelum is a rather barren constellation, with few objects of interest. The constellation's brightest star,Alpha Caeli, is only ofapparent magnitudemagnitude4.45, and only one other star (Gamma1 CaeliGamma1Caeli) is brighter than magnitude 5. Other notable objects in Caelum areRR Caeli,abinary starwith one known planet approximatelyconvert20.13pclyaway;X Caeli, aDelta Scuti variablethat forms anDouble staroptical doublewith Gamma1Caeli; andHE0450-2958, aSeyfert galaxythat at first appeared as just aastrophysical jetjetwith no host galaxy visible.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: File:Sidney Hall - Urania's Mirror - Canis Major, Lepus, Columba Noachi & Cela Sculptoris.jpgthumbleftSeen as "Cela Sculptoris" in the lower right of this 1825 star chart from ''Urania's Mirror''alt=Caelum depicted in ''Urania's Mirror''Caelum was first introduced in the eighteenth century byNicolas Louis de Lacaille, a French astronomer who introduced thirteen other southern constellations at the same time.cite webhttp://www.ianridpath.com/startales/lacaille.htmStar TalesLacailleRidpathIan3 May 2014self-publishedThe French name Lacaille gave the constellation,Burin, was originally Latinized toCaelum Scalptorium("The Engravers' Chisel"), andFrancis Bailyshortened this name toCaelumafter a suggestion byJohn Herschel.cite webhttp://www.ianridpath.com/startales/caelum.htmStar TalesCaelumRidpathIan3 May 2014self-publishedIn Lacaille's original chart, the constellation was shown both as aburinand anchoppe, although it has come to be recognized simply as a chisel.Johann Elert Bodestated the name as plural with a singular possessor,Caela Scalptoris("the Engraver's Chisels") but this did not stick.
article.heading: Characteristics
article.paragraph: Caelum is bordered byDoradoandPictorto the south,Horologium (constellation)HorologiumandEridanus (constellation)Eridanusto the east,Lepus (constellation)Lepusto the north, andColumba (constellation)Columbato the west. Covering 125square degrees, it ranks 81st of the88 modern constellationsin size. It appears prominently in the southern sky during the Southern Hemisphere's summer, and the whole constellation is visible for at least part of the year to observers south of latitude 41N.cite webhttp://www.ianridpath.com/constellations1.htmConstellations: Andromeda–IndusStar TalesRidpathIanIan Ridpathself-published1 April 2014efnWhile parts of the constellation technically rise above the horizon to observers between 41°N and 62°N, stars within a few degrees of the horizon are to all intents and purposes unobservable.<ref nameIts mainasterism (astronomy)asterismconsists of four stars, and twenty stars in total are brighter than magnitude 6.5.The constellation's boundaries, as set byEugne Joseph DelporteEugne Delportein 1930, are defined by a 12-sided polygon. In theequatorial coordinate system, theright ascensioncoordinates of these borders lie betweenRA0419.5andRA0505.1, while thedeclinationcoordinates are betweendec−27.02anddec−48.74.cite journalCaelum, Constellation BoundaryThe ConstellationsInternational Astronomical Unionhttp://www.iau.org/public/constellations/#cae14 January 2014TheInternational Astronomical Union(IAU) adopted the three-letter abbreviation "Cae" for the constellation in 1922.cite journalRussellH. N.The New International Symbols for the Constellations[[Popular Astronomy (US magazine)|Popular Astronomy]]30469–711922PA.....30..469R1922

article.heading: Stars
article.paragraph: See alsoList of stars in CaelumCaelum is a faint constellation, having no star brighter than fourthapparent magnitudemagnitudeand only two brighter than fifth magnitude. Lacaille gave six starsBayer designations, labeling them Alpha to Zeta in 1756, but omitted Epsilon and designated two nearby stars as Gamma. Bode extended the designations to Rho for other stars but most have fallen out of use.cite bookWagmanMorton2003Lost Stars: Lost, Missing and Troublesome Stars from the Catalogues of Johannes Bayer, Nicholas Louis de Lacaille, John Flamsteed, and Sundry OthersThe McDonald & Woodward Publishing Company[[Blacksburg, Virginia|Blacksburg, VA]]978-0-939923-78-658–59Caelum is too far south for any of its stars to bearFlamsteed designations.efnSouthern constellations such as Caelum have no Flamsteed designations because Flamsteed only catalogued stars that were visible from England,.<ref name14 February 2014

The brightest star,Alpha Caeli, is adouble star, containing anF-type main-sequence starof magnitude 4.45 and ared dwarfof magnitude 12.5,convert20.17pclyfrom Earth.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident* Alpha Caeli – Star in double system[[SIMBAD]]13 January 2013cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentGJ 174.1 B – Flare star[[SIMBAD]]13 January 2013Beta Caeli, another F-type star of magnitude 5.05, is further away, being locatedconvert28.67pclyfrom Earth. Unlike Alpha, Beta Caeli is asubgiantstar, slightly evolved from the main sequence.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentLTT 2063 – High proper-motion Star[[SIMBAD]]13 January 2013Delta Caeli, also of magnitude 5.05, is aB-type starB-typesubgiant and is much farther from Earth, atconvert216pcly.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident* Delta Caeli – Star[[SIMBAD]]13 January 2013

Gamma1 CaeliGamma1Caeliis a double star with ared giantprimary of magnitude 4.58 and a secondary of magnitude 8.1. The primary isconvert55.59pclyfrom Earth. The two components are difficult to resolve with small amateur telescopes because of their difference invisual magnitudeand their close separation.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident* Gamma Caeli – Star[[SIMBAD]]13 January 2013This star system forms an optical double with the unrelatedX Caeli(Gamma2Caeli), aDelta Scuti variablelocatedconvert98.33pclyfrom Earth.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentV* X Caeli – Variable Star of Delta Scuti type[[SIMBAD]]13 January 2013These are a class of short-period (six hours at most) pulsating stars that have been used asCosmic distance ladder#Standard candlesstandard candlesand as subjects to studyastroseismology.cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsots_delsctDelta Scuti and the Delta Scuti VariablesTempletonM.16 July 2010AAVSO Website[[American Association of Variable Star Observers]]2 February 2014X Caeli itself is also abinary star, specifically acontact binary,cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewX CaeliX.V. S.PatrickW.4 January 2010AAVSO WebsiteAmerican Association of Variable Star Observers28 March 2014meaning that the stars are so close that they sharestellar atmosphereenvelopes. The only other variable star in Caelum visible to the naked eye isRV Caeli, apulsating variablepulsatingred giant of spectral type M1III,cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentV* RV Caeli – Pulsating variable Star[[SIMBAD]]17 January 2013which varies between magnitudes 6.44 and 6.56.cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewRV CaeliX.V. S.25 August 2009AAVSO WebsiteAmerican Association of Variable Star Observers3 February 2014

Three other stars in Caelum are still occasionally referred to by their Bayer designations, although they are only on the edge of naked-eye visibility.Nu Caelicite webAshland Astronomy Studio: Where Art and Science ConvergeNu Caeli (HIP 22488)http://www.astrostudio.org/xhip.php?hip15 January 2014is another double star, containing awhite giantof magnitude 6.07cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentHR 1557 – Star in double system[[SIMBAD]]15 January 2013and a star of magnitude 10.66 with unknown spectral type.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentCD-41 1593B – Star in double system[[SIMBAD]]15 January 2013The system is approximatelyconvert52.55pclyaway.Lambda Caeli,cite webAshland Astronomy Studio: Where Art and Science ConvergeLambda Caeli (HIP 21998)http://www.astrostudio.org/xhip.php?hip15 January 2014at magnitude 6.24, is much redder and farther away, being a red giant aroundconvert227pclyfrom Earth.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentHR 1518 – Star[[SIMBAD]]15 January 2013Zeta Caeliis even fainter, being only of magnitude 6.36. This star, locatedconvert132pclyaway, is a K-typesubgiantof spectral type K1.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentZeta Caeli – Star[[SIMBAD]]15 January 2013The other twelve naked-eye stars in Caelum are not referred to by Bode's Bayer designations anymore, including RV Caeli.

article.heading: Deep-sky objects
article.paragraph: Due to its small size and location away from the plane of theMilky Way, Caelum is rather devoid of deep-sky objects, and contains noMessier objects. The onlydeep-sky objectin Caelum to receive much attention isHE0450-2958, an unusualSeyfert galaxy. Originally, the jet's host galaxy proved elusive to find, and this jet appeared to be emanating from nothing.Cite journalMagainP.LetaweG. R.CourbinF. D.
